segments.question: You lived where in Lodz, what street?
segments.answer: You mean before the war?

segments.question: Yeah, and then -- and then when you went to the --
segments.answer: To ghetto.

segments.question: To the ghetto.
segments.answer: Let’s see, my street nu -- street name is a very long one. It’s 28 Pulk Strzeliow Kaniowskich.

segments.question: You’re kidding me. That’s extremely long.
segments.answer: I know, crazy. It was after the first war. You have to understand, Poland was divided and not free for a few hundred years. It was the first war, and after the war that Poland become independent again. So they were honoring their troops. [indecipherable], that is 28 Battalion of Kanioski shooters rife -- riflemen.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Okay, that probably were famous in the -- one battle or another. That was -- the street was named in their honor. But it was a hell of a way to tell where you lived.

segments.question: Yeah, especially for a young kid.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: But you moved to -- when you moved into the ghetto, th-the name of the street’s really short.
segments.answer: Well, our street was Zytnia.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Zytnia means grain, wha -- what -- zhitto, rye, what e-else do we have? Rye grain --

segments.question: Wheat?
segments.answer: Wheat. Wheat Street.

segments.question: Wheat Street.
segments.answer: Zytnia.

segments.question: Hm. Had you seen this before you moved in? Did you know what it was going to look like?
segments.answer: I don’t think so.

segments.question: You don’t think so.
segments.answer: We were given the address and --

segments.question: And you went.
segments.answer: -- we moved. It was empty.

segments.question: So how many rooms did you have?
segments.answer: Pardon?

segments.question: How many rooms?
segments.answer: How about one?

segments.question: One.
segments.answer: Isn’t that enough for you? One.

segments.question: One small room?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: For you --
segments.answer: Four people. My grandmother and grandfather had another room on the same floor.

segments.question: On the same floor?
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: And is there a bathroom on that floor? I knew you were going to look at me like that. There’s- there’s nothing.
segments.answer: Outhouse.

segments.question: Outhouse.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Water? No, no water.
segments.answer: No water. Pump downstairs.

segments.question: But downstairs, so you pump the water to bring it -- so h-how do you get food? What -- what do you do for food? Is there a sm -- anything to cook on?
segments.answer: No, we --

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: -- got the ration cards, and so you had a prescribed amount of bread for a week per person. Then you had stamps to get -- to go to the grocery once, whatever, and get supplies for those stamps, which were minimal. And that’s it. Vegetables would come to the ghetto every few weeks. In wintertime they were frozen. So you ate frozen vegetables, a-and that’s it.

segments.question: So there’s very little hot meals that you’re getting?
segments.answer: Hot meals?

segments.question: Hot meals?
segments.answer: Well, you cook. You know, my mother was cooking, so she was -- you know, the women were -- that were cooking, the housewives were very ingenious in providing some meals, cooking all things possible, like making sardines out of beet leaves. You didn’t taste that, okay.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: But you roll this, the beet leave --

segments.question: So it looks like a --
segments.answer: So it looks like a sardine, you sauté it a little bit and sprinkle some salt or -- and it’s good. When you’re very hungry, everything 1s good.

segments.question: Everything is good.
segments.answer: And we were very hun -- it was unbelievable hunger. I remember, you know, Mother was scolding me once because after a year or two I look in the mirror, and I said, “Mother, now I look as I want to look.” I was close to being a skeleton, you know? I said, “Mother, isn’t that nice? I am so thin.” And for awhile I really thought so.

segments.question: You really thought so, yes.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: And she was aggravated with you?
segments.answer: Oh yes. Mm-hm.

segments.question: Did she get very thin?
segments.answer: Yes. Everybody.

segments.question: Everybody.
segments.answer: People were dying on the street --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- from hunger.

segments.question: When -- when you first move in, I understand that Rumkowski and the council began to take over certain things, sort of -- I don’t know what you want to call it -- nationalizing it for the ghetto and for his -- for his group. So there are schools --
segments.answer: He established a monarchy.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Where he was the ruler, and he has a council to help him. He established a school of which he was very proud, rightly so. Right? That was what he was doing. So consequently, I was in that school for a year, and graduated from high school, from that school, right? So that was in his favor. This school consisted of both the per -- teaching personnel and students, of remnants of people that were in the ghetto. Remnants because a lot of people from each school were missing. Either they were killed off already, or they were able to run off to Russia, for instance. You know, a good number of people survived living in Russia.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So there were sort of remnants of different student in different schools, so that was the new school. And the same went for teachers. And the director of the school was a very acknowledged woman, Mrs. Rhein, R-h-e-1-n, who was a director of one of the high schools, girl’s high schools, private high schools in Lodz city. And she, you know, directed that school. So consequently, you know, I graduated from high school. And it serves me -- served me right later. It was acknowledged by the university in Germany, this high school. Although he developed different, what we called, resorts. Resorts were really a industrial complex, not a resort like, you know, you go to for a rest.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So they had th -- see, I have very mixed feelings about Rumkowski, okay? For once, I hate him, for once I hate the whole Jewish kingdom that he built, which is no question about it. On the other hand, he did something positive. What he did was to bargain with the Germans for life, through the -- through the whole period of ghetto’s existence. So he told the German and they liked to hear that, that we will supply you with workers, and we will gi -- you first -- give you first class industries that you can use for yourself. For the price that you -- that I ca -- can keep this place alive, I can have living people working for you here. And that’s how it worked out. So at different resort, there was ro -- a resort, the industry of -- oh, I don’t know. I -- where I was working in Capol, the first one was we were ma -- a tailor industrial per -- complex, making -- making uniforms and particularly coats for the German army. And that consi -- what we were working at is -- it was called the Gummi Fabrik. You recall probably the coats that German soldier -- they were stiff like a board, right? Broad shoulders, stiff and big things here. What we were do -- the tailors were cutting them, you know, cutting out the part. We -- we were using a glue -- special glue to glue those parts together, you know, because they were double, sort of double.

segments.question: So they weren’t sewn, they were glued.
segments.answer: They were glued, yes. So -- for stiffness, and for wearability and so on, we were doing that. After we graduated, and graduated with -- with big pomp and parade. Of course, it -- the par -- the pomp was for Rumkowsk1, that he did it. We were given -- we were given work, you know, then we had to work. Otherwise we had no way of being in the ghetto. People that -- that worked could be in the ghetto. Whoever didn’t work was sent out to another camp, meaning Auschwitz, but we didn't know about that then. So we were given work. So the first place that he send us girls -- the girls, graduating girls, was to this factory of the Gummi coats, which was such a horrendous place.

segments.question: Why’?
segments.answer: It was run by man tailors of the lowest degree. And for them to get a group of intellectual girls, God, how they treated us. Was terrible.

segments.question: What’d they do?
segments.answer: Call us names, pinch us, I don’t know what else he -- they did with some other girls, not with me, but the atmosphere was just full of perversion, laughter at us. It was horrible.

segments.question: Hm. When do you -- when do you graduate? I’m just trying to get a time frame here. You hadn’t started high school when the war started.
segments.answer: 1940 we gr -- I graduated.

segments.question: In °40?
segments.answer: I think it was in °40.

segments.question: So the same year --
segments.answer: It was the year after --

segments.question: -- the same year as the ghetto starts?
segments.answer: No, that’s impossible. I don’t remember the year. Probably couple years later.

segments.question: So high -- is high school -- high school is not like American high school, it’s not four years, it’s less, right? Because you --
segments.answer: It’s 12 years, still the same.

segments.question: Right, but the high school actually starts later, am I right? Or --
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No?
segments.answer: High school is four years, high school.

segments.question: It is four years?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: But you go -- you actually graduated in less time in the ghetto, am I right? You didn’t go for four years?
segments.answer: No, but I was in the junior high school, I’ve -- I finished junior high school --

segments.question: Uh-huh. So it was the last two years.
segments.answer: -- and was to start -- yes, was to start high school --

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: -- senior high school in the ghetto.

segments.question: When you’re going to get work after you graduate, do you know the person who 1s head of the labor bureau, Bert Fuchs? Bert F-u-c-h. There’s a Fuchs --
segments.answer: In the ghetto?

segments.question: Yeah. Jewish.
segments.answer: It does not ring the bell.

segments.question: Doesn’t ring a bell.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: He was the director of what?

segments.question: The labor bureau.
segments.answer: The labor bureau.

segments.question: At a certain point there are two or three people, but at the beginning, he’s the only one.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. No, I don’t remember.

segments.question: You don’t remember, okay. Cause I thought maybe you had crossed paths or something.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So how did -- how long do you stay in that first job, a few months, few weeks?
segments.answer: Probably months. I don’t know exactly.

segments.question: How is it for your parents? Is your father a -- are your father and mother working right away, or you -- only your father?
segments.answer: My father was working. He became -- he got a job of being a -- ad -- administrator of a -- of a part of the ghetto, it’s a couple streets. They were assigned different administrator to look after the needs of the -- of the street, the needs of the building, etcetera. So he was doing that.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Mother was not working.

segments.question: So would he be -- have been considered part of -- not the Jewish Council itself, but part of the administration of the ghetto in some --
segments.answer: Mm-hm, yeah.

segments.question: -- in some way. Was -- did this mean you got more food?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No. Meant nothing.
segments.answer: Meant nothing. Meant nothing, that he was working, otherwise he would be sent out from the ghetto.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And it meant that he got some -- the money was insignificant. But got some rations, you know, maybe a little more of rations cards, though I don’t think so, 1t meant nothing.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: He was just privilege by being able to work.

segments.question: Right. Now, from my reading, I understand that in 1940 and ’41, there were a lot of worker demonstrations against Rumkowski and the -- and the Jewish Council, that the rations were insufficient, the work wasn’t sufficient, and that Rumkowski sent the Germans in, and got these people depor --
segments.answer: I don’t recall that.

segments.question: You don’t recall that?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: So you didn’t see any demon --
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: May -- maybe it was in another part of the ghetto.
segments.answer: It might have been, but I was --

segments.question: Uh-huh, but you didn’t --
segments.answer: -- it didn’t come --

segments.question: -- you weren't aware of that.
segments.answer: -- close to me.

segments.question: Right. So how did you get out of this first job? Did it just stop, or did you ask for another position?
segments.answer: .... am sort of wrestling with myself. I would like to share something with you, not about myself, and not myself, but I would not like it to get in the record. Is that possible, or I shut up?

segments.question: Well, we -- you can tell me at another time.
segments.answer: Good. But anyway, he was organizing the police, okay, Jewish police.

segments.question: Mm-hm, right.
segments.answer: You heard about that.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And he also decided to have a troop of women police -- policewomen, okay? And he took the- hi-his beloved high school graduates and sent them to the female police force, okay?

segments.question: He really liked this group of girls, huh?
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: He liked this group of --
segments.answer: It was his pride --

segments.question: Oh, his pride, uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- he did something for the future.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You know. And he was a social worker at heart, y -- it’s -- 1t’s a very mixed bag in that man.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So he -- a-and that what happened to me. Few of the girls from the -- from the -- this -- you know, tailor resort, went into the police. And we as police women were given the task to be on the street, and keep the street -- keep the street traffic in order. So we got uniforms, you know, and a office.

segments.question: What kind of uniform?
segments.answer: Green jackets with buttons.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: And green pants, yes.

segments.question: Hat?
segments.answer: Hat. And then we were in the office. I and another girl were made to be officers, you know, in charge of the troops, and above us was a elderly Czech Jew, who came from Prague. You know one thing is that to the ghetto, Lodz ghetto, there were sent Jews from all over Europe to be there and dispose with them, you know, everyplace else. So there was -- was a wonderful group of Czech Jews that came to the ghetto, okay? Mostly young students graduate, and it was such a refreshing -- I worked then at the housing department, so I met with them, you know, a lot, because they came for housing.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And they were so refreshing. I mean, innocent. They didn’t know they are Jews, or nude. You know, it was very -- a mixed culture, Jews and Gentiles. So one of the Prague guys was this elderly, handsome guy, you know, old -- pretty old, and he was in charge of [indecipherable] the women -- just -- 1t was comedy -- with another woman, a Czech woman, I think she was his assistant. So we’re sitting in the office and telling stories from Czech -- P-Prague, etcetera, etcetera. So that la-lasted for awhile, and that was disband, too. Okay, it was not such a innocent group in such a innocent job. Now, that I am talking freely because it’s about myself, not about a friend. So 1-1t -- other than keeping the traffic going -- not traffic, you know what traffic, there were no Car --

segments.question: It’s walking traffic.
segments.answer: -- walking traffic.

segments.question: Yeah, yes.
segments.answer: A-And there was other traffic. There was a lot of sewage people working, you know, sanitation, because the toilets had to be -- the outside toilets had to be cleaned regularly because of fear of epidemic, so that traffic was going. What else? And the -- the traffic to the cemetery, that was a lot, you know, a lot of people were dying. You know, picked up from the street or otherwise. Other than that, we were given a order there should not be any trade on the street. Now what kind of trade do you think there was? What there was is that people were making candies out of the sugar rations. People were making candies with a taste, and wrapped them, and then they were selling it on the street. And their order was that that trade should not exist. So we were supposed to watch for that, and if we -- when we catch a guy that is selling this candy, we were supposed to bring them to the real police, the men police. So that’s what we were doing, we were supposed to do. Now, if the real police catch a guy like that, you know where he was going.

segments.question: They’d get deported.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So it was one -- one day, I and a friend of mine from the school, my previous school, she was per -- patrolling the street and she said -- I was a officer, you see, I was not patrolling. So she says, “Paula, you have to come with me. I want you to come with me and I want to show you what we are doing, our job.” So, fine, you know, so we walked the street, and then we come to a guy that was selling candies, and she says, “Well that what I have to do, and I will do you what -- I am arresting him and bringing the -- to the police.” Which she did, and we went to the police, and she depart. And she says, “Do you know what will happen to the man?” And she says, “Do you know what we are doing here?” We spent all night walking and talking. And could not get a peace of mind. So I say, that’s it, no more, I am leaving.

segments.question: And did she do the same thing?
segments.answer: The lucky thing was that the pol -- women police was disbanded in a week from that occurrence, so we didn’t have to do anything. We were told, no more.

segments.question: Was that because the two of you said you didn’t want to do it, or --
segments.answer: No, no, independently.

segments.question: Independently.
segments.answer: Rumkowski did away with it, for whatever reason I don’t know.

segments.question: And for how long was this going on, a few months, a few week?
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Not -- but not for very long.
segments.answer: Not for very long, few months.

segments.question: And were you -- the office that you were in, were the -- was the male police -- Jewish police there also, or were you totally separate from the Jewish police?
segments.answer: Separate.

segments.question: You were separate?
segments.answer: We were separate.

segments.question: And was that your first confrontation with what that job was doing? When you went out with this woman --
segments.answer: Yes. That was.

segments.question: -- you really didn’t -- you didn’t think about it, or know what he said to [indecipherable]
segments.answer: That’s right, that’s right, mm-hm.

segments.question: Not so easy, huh?
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: Not easy.
segments.answer: Oh, horrible. But that what it was. The police was helping Rumkowski keeping order --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- and keeping the deal with the Germans.

segments.question: And did you have opinions then about the male Jewish police?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: You want to tell me?
segments.answer: The male Jewish police wasn -- no question about that they were fully cooperated with Rumkowski and therefore with the Germans, and we had no good opinion about them.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Were you afraid of them?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: And they were very helpful at the time of getting Jews into the transport going to Auschwitz. I tell you, it was horrible, the thought that Jewish police is helping Germans. It was horrible. I changed my mind a bit watching Lanzmann’s movie. You know, when he interviews the Sonderkommando in Auschwitz, and you saw people that were really on the other side, in Auschwitz, helping Germans to kill Jews, frankly to kill Jews.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: And I got away with a different feeling. How can you blame people that were forced to do the job, knowing they are going to be killed in four months, how can you blame them?

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: It was very powerful.

segments.question: On the other hand -- let me give you the other hand here.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: You couldn’t do it. You couldn't do something that was in a way simpler, but was part of a process.
segments.answer: No, I couldn’t do it.

segments.question: And it was something that you couldn’t do.
segments.answer: That’s right.

segments.question: So --
segments.answer: And I’m sure other people couldn’t either.

segments.question: Right. So some could, and maybe they could live with themselves and maybe they couldn’t, but they did it anyway.
segments.answer: That’s right. That -- you’re right. And in Auschwitz, you know, the Sonderkommando that did work, you know, the gas chambers and the crematoria, some were just picked and forced to do it.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: They had no way out other than go --

segments.question: And be killed. Right.
segments.answer: -- right away.

segments.question: Right. You ever think what would have happened if everybody said no?
segments.answer: There would be a revolution, and maybe successful.

segments.question: It’s hard to do that though, isn’t it?
segments.answer: That’s why the big problem was, you know, is -- Hannah -- what was her name, Hannah --

segments.question: Hannah Arendt.
segments.answer: Arendt, accusing Jews in Poland that they went like sheep to the gas chambers.

segments.question: Actually, she didn’t.
segments.answer: No?

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Who did? Where did that come from?

segments.question: I don’t know. Sometimes the resistance said that.
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: Sometimes the resistance, the partisans --
segments.answer: Uh-huh.

segments.question: -- said don’t go like sheep.
segments.answer: Oh, I see, yes.

segments.question: She never s --
segments.answer: But she didn’t.

segments.question: She didn’t say it.
segments.answer: I see, okay, so --

segments.question: But it’s a --
segments.answer: Excuse me.

segments.question: No, but it’s a -- it’s an accusation that people think she said things like that --
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- she didn’t. She -- she was not happy with the councils, but she never blamed the rest of the Jews. She thought that the councils shouldn’t have cooperated. That, yes, but she never said that other.
segments.answer: And this gave me also another thought, you know, when I was in August in Lédz --

segments.question: Oop, w-we have to stop? Okay, we’ll stop. Sorry.
segments.answer: Finish later.

data: Yes, we’ll finish it later. End of Tape Four Beginning Tape Five

segments.question: Okay. We forgot something. When you were talking about being in high school, weren’t you at some point in something called a farm settlement that we didn’t talk about? What was that? Was that while you were in high school? Was that part of the high school?
segments.answer: That was part of Rumkowsk1’s plan. As you know, he was a social worker and director of an orphanage before the war. He also was a great Zionist. And at the -- at the time when the school opened, he gave us a proposition that whoever would volunteer can go to this place that was part of the ghetto, but 1t was sort of more rural, and it was a old house that used to be a orphanage. Not his orphanage, but the Polish population. And that we would, boys and girls go there and learn farming in preparation for the -- to go into Palestine and become kibbutznik farmers. So, you know, we needed to have the permission of our parents, and then a group of us went there. And we spent a full year there. And it was a wonderful time, a time that permit us who were willing to be there, to forget where we were. It was out of this world, really. It was a huge house, a orphanage, you know, so there was big halls. And our group was probably not more than 20 boys and girls. Boys separate, girls separate bedrooms, etcetera. And in the morning we would go to school. We would go by -- by carriages, you know, we had some people that were bringing u -- by horse and buggy, big buggy, to school, and then afternoon we would come to the farm. We call it Hak’shara, which is Hebrew for farm. And it has the Zionist implication, but we couldn’t give a damn about -- at that time about the implication of Palestine, 1t was just a lovely place. It was a farm that used to be used -- you know, it was used by Poles as a farm, and also had animals. It had goats, and chickens, etcetera. And there was one guy, he was a German Jew who was a farmer, and knew about, you know, farming, and other than going to school, homework, etcetera, he would teach us what to do. In other word, we would sow seeds, and all kinds of thing, and take care of the growing crop. There was a orchard, and there were the animals. The animals we would -- let’s see, there were some cows, and there were some goats, and we would learn how to milk them. And then distru -- distribute the milk by buggies, and -- horse and buggies to cooperative, to stores, you know, run by the -- by Rumkowski that will be selling it to the population on carts and so on. So it was a ideal love -- life, really. Very gratifying. Of course, we paired up, boys and girls, and so were some romances going and that was, under the circumstances, unheard of. We -- of course, were properly chaperoned by mothers that would take turn and come for overnight to be with -- with the -- you know, with us, to make sure nothing was happening. So that was the --

segments.question: Did they really stop things from happening?
segments.answer: I think, in a way, yes. So that was the time, and it was a lot of camaraderie, and there’s sa -- were some evening that we had music, some of the people play [indecipherable] particularly played the piano, and there was a piano. So we had music, and we were dancing. You know, so we were cooking [indecipherable] for the crew, you know. So we would take turns for 24 hours to prepare meals, a boy and a girl, cou -- you know, prepare breakfast, lunch, dinner, and etcetera. So it was a unbelievable year.

segments.question: So you were staying there as opposed to being with your parents and your sister.
segments.answer: That’s right, that’s right.

segments.question: Right. Did you have a boyfriend?
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Was this a boyfriend from before, or somebody that you met in this group?
segments.answer: Somebody who I met in this group.

segments.question: In group?
segments.answer: Yes, mm-hm.

segments.question: And how many boys and girls were there, do you think?
segments.answer: Altogether close to 20. 18 - 20.

segments.question: Did you mother ever -- was she ever --
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: -- chaperone?
segments.answer: Yes, yes, she agreed to.

segments.question: They never took the fathers for a chaperone, only the mothers.
segments.answer: Yes, cause [indecipherable] why, why, why -- I don’t know why.

segments.question: And was this er -- wi -- like in 42 -- 1942, do you think? Do you have any recollection what year? I mean, I know it’s hard to figure out what years these things are.
segments.answer: °42 - °43. Something like that.

segments.question: I was just trying to figure it out in relationship to the work that you were doing.
segments.answer: It was before.

segments.question: It was before --
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- right, because you were still in high school.
segments.answer: That’s right [indecipherable] said before high school. And then, when we graduate from high school, what happened? O-Of course, the farm disbanded, why did it disband? Times got tougher politically. I think Rumkowski did not have any more ji -- way of thinking and doing to supervise or insist, or we simply -- that what happened, it was disband and we were given jobs.

segments.question: So you --
segments.answer: We were needed to work. We had to stop and we are needed to -- to work for the Germans.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You know we --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- we -- we were needed to pay off.

segments.question: So this is that same class, that last graduating class in the high school that you talked about before, yes?
segments.answer: Right, yes. There was another class after us, so two classes graduated.

segments.question: But they didn’t have this opportunity.
segments.answer: They’re -- the --

segments.question: The farm.
segments.answer: They didn’t come to the farm.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: I don’t remember why, or the times already toughened and, you know, there was no -- no time for frivolities, so to speak.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So we were the only group that did it, that had this privilege, really. Oh f --

segments.question: And did you --
segments.answer: -- yes?

segments.question: I’m sorry. Did you then go back to live with your parents and sister?
segments.answer: Actually, I never went back to live with my parent again. I was emancipated. Oh, there was another job immediately after, that was -- so many jobs in such a short time, so it --

segments.question: That’s okay.
segments.answer: -- sort of get mixed up. Hm?

segments.question: It’s okay if it gets mixed up.
segments.answer: Yes. One job was making, you know, in -- in a production of houses, what you call houses that you build part -- parts for it.

segments.question: Prefabricated?
segments.answer: Prefabr -- prefabricated homes for export to Germany, okay? So some of us went to work on that, and we got housing there, also outside, you know, the main part of the ghetto. And we -- we were living there totally, and working. So that was -- lasted for awhile, and that was finished. Now, we were doing the -- the prevat -- prefabricated parts with cement, mixing cement, pouring it into forms, taking out -- you know, we learned the whole production of how do you do -- how you do it. And that ended. But another job that I had was working in a kitchen, and that was the best job. An-And really ended badly. There was a occasion to go to work for a kitchen that was established -- kitchen restaurant, so to speak, establish by Rumkowski that was producing dinners one -- once a day dinners for people that work in different kind of industries and were given a bonus to come to this -- to this kitchen for a dinner, for a week or two weeks or so. It was a extra sort of a pay-off for good work and so on. And working in that kitchen, of course it was wonderful, because you could eat, okay? You didn’t have to be hungry, right? So -- and it was nice, there was a nice by -- bunch of girls, familiar also from the school, and it was nice to work there. We made hamburgers, we do this, we chopped up all kind that was needed 1n the kitchen, under the supervise -- supervision of women cooks. And then what happened was that there was a Sonderkommando older guy, you know, that I and he knew each other, I don’t remember from where, but there were no hard feelings bet -- between us, there was some hostility. I don’t know what -- what was the cause, but at any rate, he was on duty one day, and I went -- supposedly I was asking the cook that was serving the soup -- I was serving -- you know, the guy that -- the Czech that was supervising the women police, and he was there e -- as a client, and I suppose that he asked the server to give me a little more in the plate of soup, because I wanted to, you know. And this Kohn, Kohn was his name, caught me doing that, and therefore did saw that I was kicked out from the kitchen, from my good job. Himself was a -- a s-son of a gun, you know, terrible guy to get to be accused of anything. And -- an-and -- and that was it, so that job ended, and I was sent, as a punishment, I was sent to a -- to a resort, a -- a factory that was making stuff out of wood. That means they were making wooden chairs, wooden wagons, you know, wheels, wooden wheels. It was a huge factory, under one roof, you know, just huge, full of machineries that produced a lot of dust when you worked them. So that was my punishment. I was sent to Siberia, and I was there for about a year or so. It was a tough year, really. Hard work, a lot of dust, and I was punished, you know, that was punishment. So what can I say.

segments.question: And you were agai -- still living away from your parents. You -- you had found your own place?
segments.answer: No. At this time I think I went back --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- home, cause there was no place to -- to be. So -- but I found a very nice friend there, working around the young people and we chummed together. And so from the social point of view, it was nice.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Except that it was a dirty job.

segments.question: Right. Now, is this after you were in the women’s police force? Do you --
segments.answer: I think it was before, probably.

segments.question: You think it was before?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Okay.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. So -- a-and you know, my encounter with this Sonderpoliceman was as we were the last day in the ghetto, as we were transported to Auschwitz, you know, before -- before being [indecipherable] to the -- you know, to the wagons, y-you know, that take us. And there was I and this policeman, and I looked at him and I didn’t say a word, just thinking, you scoundrel. Here you are and here I am.

segments.question: Right. Here you go.
segments.answer: Common ending --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- of the story. So that was part of my life.

segments.question: What’s happening to you as a young woman? You’re 20 -- in 1942, two years after the -- the ghetto was formed, you’re 20 -- 20 years old.
segments.answer: Yes, 19 - 20, yes.

segments.question: 19 - 20 years old.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: What kind of a person are you becoming? Are you -- you clearly -- as you tell the story, you clearly have moments when things are not so terrible. You’re meeting friends, you have friends, there’s something -- thing -- there are things that make you happy. But clearly, there’s an underlying something that must be very wearing on you. Are you depressed, are you --
segments.answer: I think the motto for that being then is we shall overcome.

segments.question: You really felt that.
segments.answer: Oh yeah.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Yes. And in the family too, you know. We didn’t know the song we shall -- you know, that --

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: -- that black people brought and led the -- the Civil Rights Movement.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But that was what kept us going. We shall overcome. And the motto was life, keep on living.

segments.question: So you didn’t give up?
segments.answer: Oh, no.

segments.question: In spite of everything that you knew.
segments.answer: Right. And neither would my mother or father, or within the close-knit family.

segments.question: They didn’t give up either.
segments.answer: No. We shall overcome. And, you know, listening to the ri -- radio --

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: -- and of course we had to give up when the German came, first among their rules was all radios you bring to this place in Lodz, and sewing machines and all machinery, guns of course, you know, etcet -- etcetera. So if you were caught listening to -- to the radio, you could be deported.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But I want -- I wanted to say you can get killed, but deported was --

segments.question: The same.
segments.answer: -- equals death.

segments.question: The same thing, yeah.
segments.answer: So -- so no radio, no listening to the radio. So we didn’t know, but somehow some rumors were crossing, some people were listening to the radio. You know, they dared and they were listening to it. And I think my father had some connection with somebody that got the news. So we knew broadly what was happening, and we knew where the Germans were, you know, the trip to Siberia, and Stalingrad. And also what we knew that at that time he had all Europe under his hand, right? And -- and fighting England and bombing London, and so on. So we knew what was th -- and some of the news were brought by people that were deported from Paris and Vienna, and yi -- all your Holland, Dutch people, Czech -- Czech people, they were bringing news because they still knew what was going on, closer than we did. So we knew that he has by now all Europe under -- under his foot, and that there’s little hope really, of very -- very m -- very changes that could happen in immediate future. So you just had to take a -- a long view to the future, we shall overcome, in spite of everything that is happening. So you have to be strong. And one thing that became very important in every day life was how you live with almost nothing. That the ration that you got from the bakery, that piece of bread that you got per person, and you are in charge of it, it has to last you all week. Don’t eat it in one setting. Because people that did, died. People that didn’t lost weight, and died too, some that could not go on and got some infection and so on. So how do you do that? Families that could do that, and my mother was the leader of it, we did it under her supervision. We stemmed the hunger and take very -- took very little, could survive and hope for later. Many people could not, and died just because they could not do it.

segments.question: Did you smoke?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Did a lot of people smoke then?
segments.answer: I take it back.

segments.question: You take it back, you did smoke?
segments.answer: My first experiment with smoking was when I was in the police fers -- force, and this guy, the Czech guy and his assistant were smoking, and I say, hey, let me try it. So I tried, and I got sick. Dizzy, and so on, and I gave it up. But I smoked later, for a few years, you know, after the war.

segments.question: After the war.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: The reason I ask is because many people smoked because it’s -- I don’t know if it stops hunger, but you don’t seem to be -- necessarily eat as much if you’re smoking. So I thought possibly that was --
segments.answer: I didn’t get to that stage.

segments.question: You didn’t get to that stage. So you -- you and your family were very disciplined about the rationing of food.
segments.answer: Oh yes, yes.

segments.question: Your sister is much younger, was it more difficult for her because she was so much younger? Or was she old enough to understand by --
segments.answer: I -- she was old enough --

segments.question: -- she must have been, she was a teenager.
segments.answer: -- and she was a smart little gi-girl.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Right. Let me ask you something about Rumkowsk1i. I interviewed someone, Lucille Eichengreen, who both -- she wrote about and -- a-about her own experiences, and experiences of other people with Rumkowski.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: That he was abusing young women, sometimes boys. It happened in the orphanage, according to her, and it -- then it happened in [indecipherable]
segments.answer: You mean before the war?

segments.question: Before the war.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Pedophile.

segments.question: And in the ghetto, as well. And I wondered if you heard anything or knew anything about Rumkowski and what he did. Because we don’t -- we can’t -- she’s the only person who has been willing to talk about it, and she only talked about it once everybody she knew was dead, so she wouldn’t hurt --
segments.answer: Mm-hm. I see. I knew that -- but not directly -- and I never had any interview with him, though people would go asking for special things, and would have a need to talk with him. I never had the need, I never met him personally. But I heard that he wa -- you know, that if you want a audience with him, you have to be prepared that he will sexually assault you. So I heard -- that was floating rumors all over, and to be believed. Now, I know about his life something else. He got married in -- in the ghetto, you know, and his wife lived in the house -- same house that we lived. And he was -- she was a lawyer, so-called a old maid, you know? I don’t know if she was 30 or 31 or 29, but she was all -- already old. You know, according. And he married her, so I saw him come, you know, to the house, walking into the house and that -- few times, and that’s it. Then when they were married, I suppose she lived with him not -- not in that house where I lived. So why he got married, I don’t know, but who’s to say?

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: So, I think -- a-as you know, he was the last transport, both of them went to Auschwitz.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And did not survive.

segments.question: Right. Of course, there are different rumors about that, he was killed by people who had been in Lodz, or he was gassed, who knows?
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Nobod -- nobody is sure.
segments.answer: No, I don’t know --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- anything beyond that.

segments.question: Do you remember the speech he gave in September of 1942, give me your children, were you there? What was that like?
segments.answer: The worst day in the world. He gathered a lot of people, cause 1t was known that he will give the speech, so people came. And we knew that it cannot be any good news, so you know, that was in the air. And he gave a speech. He was a good speaker, you know, telling how much he cares, telling how much work he puts in -- into survival, and do the best for the population, and we should believe him and trust him. And in that vein, he wants to tell us that it 1s up to us to prevent any big loss of population, the Germans gave him a number of children between the ages- I don’t remember, young children, but not too young, you know, the -- they -- the Germans will bring those children to a special care -- camp, that they will get a very good care, better than in the ghetto, that he can assure us will happen, and that will allow the ghetto to survive til war is ended. So please, mothers, go home, prepare the children. Give them, you know, prepare something, clothing, some dishes to eat from. And it was not the dep -- you know, the collection, such and such day. That was it. And there was, of course, a lot of crying and screaming, and the people dispersed. It was paralyzing, you know, paralyzing fear and anger. But what bothers -- bothered me worst, as we ma -- were making our way home, I don’t know if wha -- my mother came or not, I know I was, and I was by myself, so I don’t remember. What bothered me most 1s I was walking back home and some neighbors wi -- with me were walking too, how quickly those women adjusted to that idea. I -- I couldn't understand that. Mainly -- mainly accepting his premise, believing him, and saying we need to do what he say, and maybe that way we’ ll save our children. So they were eager to go home and prepare their children for that. I almost died then.

segments.question: Because you didn’t believe it.
segments.answer: Not a word.

segments.question: Did you say anything to these women that you heard, or you just kept quiet and walked?
segments.answer: No, but I went home, we talked and non -- nobody home believed that either. Many people did not believe that.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But I was surprised how many people did believe.

segments.question: Right. Yeah.
segments.answer: So immediately.

segments.question: Paula, do you think what -- what do you think Rumkowski thought he was telling people? Did he believe that these kids would be okay? Did he not know?
segments.answer: I don’t think he was so dumb. I he -- I think really that he was calculating. In his work with [indecipherable] the other German, he was simply calculating how to save most of Jews, how to help as many as possible Jews to survive. And that’s how he was making the deals.

segments.question: So as long as he could save some, it wouldn’t matter?
segments.answer: Yeah. Against liquidating the whole ghetto. That could have happened.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You know, the Germans just could come and erase the ghetto, you know, any time, either by bomb or sending out people. They had the power.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: It -- so he was calculating how to make the best deal against that possibility. I think he was sincere about it.

segments.question: About doing that?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yes. Have you heard that speech again?
segments.answer: Pardon?

segments.question: Have you ever read his speech again?
segments.answer: No, no. Is there -- is there --

segments.question: Yeah, I have it.
segments.answer: On what, on paper?

segments.question: Now I have it on paper, but I believe it’s on tape. Some -- somehow you can hear his words.
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Mm, I would be interested in hearing it.

segments.question: Let me -- let me just read you the last part of it for a second.
segments.answer: Yes, okay.

segments.question: “A broken Jew stands before you,” he said. “Do not envy me. This is the most difficult of all the orders I’ve ever had to carry out at any time. I reach out to you with my broken, trembling hands and I beg, give in to my hands the victims, so that we can avoid having further victims. And a population of a hundred thousand Jews can be preserved. So they promise me. If we deliver our victims by ourselves, there will be peace.” It’s quite a speech. But he clearly was trying to also talk about how difficult this was for him.
segments.answer: Oh yes. I believe that.

segments.question: Yeah. And you do believe it.
segments.answer: I -- yes.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: He was a politician, and traded in human life.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And from the point of view as I told you when -- last August I saw this fairly large number of survivors of the ge -- lo -- ghetto Lodz, I said, that is because of Rumkowsk1. Not that I love him, or admire him.

segments.question: No, right.
segments.answer: But that’s a fact.

segments.question: So the deal with the devil --
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: -- worked 1n some respects.
segments.answer: That’s what I think. And the death of the president in Warsaw ghetto didn’t produce anything but a loss of one human life.

segments.question: Czerniakow.
segments.answer: Czerniakow.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Yes. That doesn’t say that I would not, given m-myself and that choice, I probably would kill myself rather than stand like Rumkowski, saying that. But in judging, what is more pr -- I want to say productive -- of what is more -- I don’t -- I don’t find a word for it.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I -- I -- I cannot hate Rumkowski for it. You know I have some respect for him for that. And for his pain, as he was saying.

segments.question: Right, right. D-Do you have any recollection of when you -- I know that you thought that the Germans were going to kill Jews.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: But the -- but they don’t start murdering until 1941. There’s some murders, but there’s no -- the Einsatzgruppen come with the attack on Russia in 1941, and the -- the killing centers start in 41 and °42, and the major killings are f -- 1942. When is it that you realize that what you think is going to happen 1s really happening? Do you know? Is it in the middle of the ghetto, is 1t when- y-you have a friend who comes with her daughter to the Lodz ghetto -- I mean, she becomes a friend of yours. Now, this may be towards the end, I don’t know if this is 1942 or it’s later, 1944, and she won’t give up her daughter.
segments.answer: Oh -- oh, you -- oh, the story that I told.

segments.question: Yes, yes.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Is -- is she the one who convinced you that what you thought was happening was really happening, or did you think that before?
segments.answer: Ire -- since 1939 and before, listening to Hitler did not think that he is talking kwotch.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And that the “Mein Kampf” book is just a book of a sick mind. We took him very seriously, and I know we were listening to the radio for hours. The -- his speeches were transmitted live as it was happening in Berlin or wherever, so we had a chance to listen to the radio, and sort of judging the speeches, and my father, my mother, myself, we knew he is speaking the truth, and that we have nothing to hope for if he 1s a-allowed to bring his plan forth. That is France, England -- we didn't talk about America, that was sort of, you know, outside of Europe. Unless they come and stop him, he will bring it to fruition, kill us. How, what, when, that was unknown, but we -- this projection we had way back.

segments.question: So I guess when -- maybe you can repeat the story that you told about this friend, during the de -- it -- it -- that you told in the shi -- in the -- in the film, “Shoah.” Not in the film, in the -- in the interview that you did --
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: -- it wasn’t in the film, because it appeared as if it had a-an enormous impact.
segments.answer: It was not in the film?

segments.question: What? No.
segments.answer: He didn’t put it in the film?

segments.question: Mm-mm.
segments.answer: Hm.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Okay, yes --

segments.question: No, your portion --
segments.answer: -- yes.

segments.question: -- in the film was --
segments.answer: I know. That -- that’s right, I forget.

segments.question: -- it -- it was -- it was much smaller.
segments.answer: Yes, yes.

segments.question: But this is a story about this woman who comes in, she must be in her 20’s, maybe not so much older than you --
segments.answer: That’s right, that’s right --

segments.question: -- with the daughter.
segments.answer: -- yes, in 20’s. And I know that I work then -- then I worked in the housing department, and she came from the line, you know, she is from a little town, she named the town, you know, close to Lodz. And she says 1s -- she is with the daughter so she needs housing for herself and the daughter. Her husband was the Alteste of the -- of the -- the small Jewish community. He was taken away and killed with others, and she is here. And in my heart was going out to her, she was- so [ -- there was a room in my -- in the house that I was living, so I told her to go there and see, and if it is okay, she can move in. And then I started to contact with her and we -- we became good friends and talked, you know, a lot. And she was telling me about the life there, and th -- and you know that in the end, 1-1t w-was just killed off then -- you know, and she is sent here, etcetera. So, it was nice to have -- she was a very warm, smart woman, and a cute kid, nine years old, a little girl. And then it came, you know, the speech of Rumkowsk1, and she said never. You know, I will never give up my child. So we still had few days to talk about it, so we talked at length, and I said, “My God, what are you going to do?” So she said, “Never will I give up voluntarily my daughter.” And I agreed with her, you know, I -- I was not quarreling. And then the day came of our street being run, you know, with SS troops, and coming, and they ask all population of a given building to go in the backyard and line up. And two, three SS guys with, you know, bayonets came into the yard. I was standing close to my fre -- I forget her name -- close to my friend. And they said -- announced, all children of this and this age, please come. And she was holding the girl’s hand tightly. And, you know, she was not budging. Other kids came forth. And then the SS guy comes to her and says, bring -- takes the girl’s hand and wants to pull her away, and she said no. And he said in German, “If you don’t let go, I will shoot you.” And she says, “Okay, shoot me.” So he takes her by the neck, turns her around, and puts the revolver to her neck and shoots. And she falls to my feet, on my feet. And I hardly could stand. And he took the girl.

segments.question: Anyway. Right.
segments.answer: You see?

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Rumkowsk1’s philosophy a-and the reality, and how can you say anything, just don’t ask me any questions about it, cause there are no answers. For three days I could not talk and could not eat, and my mother started to worry about me. And then there was no choice but to live.

segments.question: I’m not sure exactly what I ha -- I have thoughts in my -- my head, I’m not quite sure what to ask you about this because I -- on the one hand I thought to myself, she -- she had to know they would take her daughter no match you -- no matter what she did, and worse comes to worse they would shoot her and then the daughter would die, too.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And so I’m just wondering, what was -- what -- what must have been going through -- and you don’t know what was going through her head, because she had to know if they were going to shoot her, they were going to take the daughter.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And I guess one would just say it was an impossible situation whichever way she did it, she was going to die.
segments.answer: But she was not going to agree.

segments.question: Agree to it, period.
segments.answer: Give her life first before agreeing. I can understand that. Over my dead body, it says.

segments.question: Right, right. Ri-Right.
segments.answer: Literally.

segments.question: Yes. And the daughter was -- you think was gassed?
segments.answer: Sure.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Unless by some fluke she could escape or something.

segments.question: Right, right. Was this the first time you saw a dead person?
segments.answer: Oh no, you could see many dead people on the streets of the ghetto.

segments.question: But this was somebody you knew, and pretty well.
segments.answer: Yeah -- ye -- my grandmother died in the ghetto. My -- my uncle died in the ghetto.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: So I went to the funerals of my family.

segments.question: And so they’re buried in Lodz.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And after three days you said, I have to go on.
segments.answer: Yes, somehow I revived.

segments.question: So this was 1942, this was in the middle --
segments.answer: Mm-hm

segments.question: -- of the ghetto. But deportation meant death to you, that was clear.
segments.answer: It was not clear, but it was clear.

segments.question: It wasn’t known, but it was --
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: -- the intent was clear.
segments.answer: How did we -- there were people that came to the ghetto, some people that lived in the ghetto in Lodz, and were deported, and somehow run away and came, you know, sort of on the black -- black side --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- to the ghetto, and they brought news. One first news was about Chelmno. You -- y-you -- you know the name.

segments.question: Yes, I was going to ask you, yes.
segments.answer: That was -- that was a small time -- town, not far from the city, and that is where the first experiment with gas were done in buses. So those guys that escaped, escaped that, but they were witness to what’s going on, and escape. So we knew about the gassing, etcetera. Then there were other news, also from peop -- you know, we got a lot of mail from people that were deported, that they are in camp like that, and everything is fi -- you know, that was all hoax. But some people came, and they brought news from Auschwitz, and that we could not believe, that there were factories to gas people and burn their bodies, crematoria. We could not believe, but they were circulate -- those news were circulating.

segments.question: But Chelmno you believed?
segments.answer: Pardon?

segments.question: People believed what was going on in -- in Chelmno --
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: -- but not Auschwitz?
segments.answer: That’s right. I -- are -- or -- impossible. And it -- but those were people they were talking about, so it was sort of, we don’t want to believe that, but --

segments.question: Right, right, right.
segments.answer: -- hey, you have to pay attention.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So there were news like that of what’s happening in the world.

segments.question: Was there a lot of corruption in Lodz, you think? That’s a -- that’s a lot, huh?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: It’s inevitable though, isn’t it, under those circumstances, since there’s no -- was there a black market? Even though it was so isolated, there was a black market?
segments.answer: I think so.

segments.question: So when I say was there corruption and you look the way you did, what 1s it -- what -- what is it that’s going through your head?
segments.answer: Through my s -- head 1s I ca -- I -- I cannot tell her anything concrete that I know, any facts [indecipherable] he told me so, but I know there was.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Part of the cor -- not corruption but sort of tangentially, wer -- my experience was following. My father was working, I was working, my sister was 1n school for a couple of years and then she got some job to work. My mother was not working. And we began to worry about it because she could be the next deported person. So the question was how do we get -- we need to get her a job. Who will get her a job? My father could not hit right. And then was the -- also the peculiar situation in ghetto of reversed roles. You know, the people -- kids like myself that were coming of age in the ghetto, but they were children in school, but by the time it was going on, they were 17 - 18. There was the support of the -- of the ghetto. That on them leaned the economy of life in the ghetto. Those were the people with strength, that could work and buy time for Rumkowski from the Germans. So all of the sudden I became very important in the group -- in the populati -- in the, you know, population. And influential. So my father said, “Well you have to do something.” But what can I do? We have to do something. At this time I was working 1n this housing department which had couple bosses, one older man, and his assistant -- I forget their names, Wolf -- one was Wolfe, the young one was Wolfe, and the older I don’t remember. And the -- you know, older guy and his assistant was the younger guy, and they -- you know, we had very good relationship, they respected me, I respected them, 1-it was nice. So I said, I have to go to both of them and ask if they can find a job for Mother. It was a dangerous step, because you had to pay. And what does a young girl pay? How does a young girl pay? Sex, right? So that was written in big letters. Am I willing to pay that for my mother getting a job? I had to count on that, when I go to one or the other. That’s how Rumkowski comes in that category, too. When people came, women, particularly young women came to him with begging for some favor, like for a sick person to get some medicine, or what n -- extraordinary thing, they had to pay. So I said, what do I do? And I cannot talk to Father about that. So I said, well, God help me, and I go to both of them. But to one, the older one, he was a chief, and tell him such and such, and I need a job for Mother, to keep her alive. What can I tell you my surprise that he didn’t ask for a prize, and he got Mother a job in a kitchen in some resort, you know, in some factory. And Mother started to work. I was surprised, but pleasantly, you know?

segments.question: Absolutely.
segments.answer: So that was a one thing. The other thing was Mother worked in that factory, the director was Mrs. Sandberg, who was the father of my classmate in grade school, and we knew each other -- I forgot her name, first name, but not closely, but she -- she was a nice kid and I think she thought me, too. I knew her parents from all kinds of affairs for kids. Her father had a horrible opinion, you know, as a explorator, as a bad guy, as nobody to talk to, y -- just -- that was the opinion of Mrs. -- about Mr. Sandberg. Her mother was a nice lady. Mother was very happy working there. I told you my mother s -- wished to work --

segments.question: Yes. She finally --
segments.answer: -- and she could not. She got a job. And was she happy. She really was happy. She was going in the morning, she worked in the kitchen, peeling potatoes, all kinds of stuff, but being among a bunch of women -- my mother was an excellent talker, you know, and communi -- you know, sort of with people, she was a -- enjoyed it and was liked, and she would come back with stories. And I said, “Mother, I never saw you so happy.” And also, in the kitchen, we -- they were allowed some stealing. They could take some -- first of all, they were allowed to do is to bring home potato peels. Something that you throw out.

segments.question: Throw away, yes.
segments.answer: Potato peels.

segments.question: It’s good for you, right?
segments.answer: Absolutely.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: That was delicious food. Mother would cook a kugel from potato peels.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Yes, and all kind of things. So it was food for the family. And she smuggled few potatoes with it, so we had few potatoes. So she was double happy for herself and that she could bring something home from the job. Make me very happy, you know, it was just nice to see that woman, under those conditions really thriving. Then one day comes the order through Mr. Sandberg, as it was coming to all directors of the factories, to supply by that date, that many workers of his to send out to -- for relocation. It was called relocation, to another ghetto. Right? So Mother is in danger, and in serious danger. And what do I do? Mother says, go and talk to Mr. Sandberg.

segments.question: This time Mother says it, uh-huh.
segments.answer: I may be sent out. Oh. I was beside myself. I didn’t want to go. He’s a mean -- I say, “Mother, he is a mean man, I may make it worse.” And she says, “Don’t worry, just go and talk to him.” I walked the streets around my house half of the night, what do I do, what do I do? So I did -- first of all I went to talk to Mrs. Sandberg, the wife. And she knew me, you know, I was a classmate of her daughter, and I said, look, such and such, I don’t know what to ask you for, but please understand where we are. She didn’t say anything, yes, no, whatever, nothing. And then I made an appointment to see Mr. Sandberg, and I did see him, and he was nice enough. Not nice really, but polite enough. And I begged him for my mother’s life. Well, he didn’t put her on the list. But you asked me what were the fi -- feeling, living like that. You see this horror of those feelings? And horror of ever -- of being forced, not by my parents, by what’s going on, to do something that you may think that you contribute to your mother’s death one way or another. Could have happened very easily.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: He could have said, I have no choice. What would you do in my place?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Things like that. But that worked out that way. How does it leave you internally? Certainly not with a feeling of power. A feeling of rage, of anger, that you cannot get riv -- rid of through your lifetime.

segments.question: Do you also think of the other side, your mother saved, but somebody else goes? [indecipherable |
segments.answer: That’s true, but I didn’t think that far.

segments.question: Not then, no.
segments.answer: Mm-mm. But of course somebody -- you know, there was --

segments.question: Yes, somebody’s got to go.
segments.answer: -- yes. He had to -- he had to produce the number of people --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- the Germans wanted. Rumkowski and the Germans wanted.

segments.question: But to go beg for someone’s life is not -- it’s not what one wants to do in life.
segments.answer: No.
