segments.question: C-Can I ask you something about Auschwitz for just a second? Because it’s -- unless I misheard you, you said that you were taken from the hospital back to Birkenau.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So does that mean the hospital you were in was not in Birkenau? You were in Auschwitz one?
segments.answer: No, no. I --

segments.question: Or you were in another part of Birkenau?
segments.answer: Another part of Birkenau.

segments.question: Okay. And did they take you bay truck back to your barracks? Is that what they did? Or you don’t remember?
segments.answer: I remember it being on the train. So maybe it was Auschwitz, you know, the real Auschwitz camp, not Birkenau, but it was a distance. The hospital was a distance from the Birkenau barracks.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: So they were taking us back to the barrack parts.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And then we had to walk a bit and go to the barracks.

segments.question: Do you remember what barrack it was?
segments.answer: Number? No, I don’t.

segments.question: Do you remember whether it was on the far right, where the -- they used to call Mexico, or --
segments.answer: I don’t remember Mexico.

segments.question: -- you don’t remember the ba --
segments.answer: Mm-mm. 0

segments.question: You didn’t say, but I’m assuming that your sister was taken.
segments.answer: Yeah.

segments.question: She was. And that was --
segments.answer: The end.

segments.question: -- that was the end.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So you were not able to say good-bye, nothing?
segments.answer: Well, that I think was the worst day in my whole experience about Auschwitz.

segments.question: Was that.
segments.answer: Was that. That day. That always in my mind, you saved your life, but you could not save your sister.

segments.question: Even though you know that you couldn’t have saved her.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: It still -- and it’s the same with your parents, in your head.
segments.answer: Stronger.

segments.question: Stronger?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: That you somehow should have been able --
segments.answer: Yes. Cause in a symbolic way, my mother in Auschwitz, gave me the job to take care of my sister. And the symbolic way was that before we entered -- before we were parted, she gave me a little handkerchief with few jewelry pieces, her pieces, few ri -- you know, that was not much to talk about, but few rings, and a necklace of hers. And she gave it to me, and says -- she said, take care. 1

segments.question: You’re not over it yet. I guess there’s no getting over it. So I can’t say anything.
segments.answer: Hm?

segments.question: I can’t say anything. I can’t take it away. I'd like to take it away from you. But you also feel as if you’re responsible for your parent’s deaths.
segments.answer: Yes. But especially for my sister, because of that exchange. And then later I was not so clear, but later I said, well she kid not -- could not mean the few pieces of gold, she meant my sister, to take care of.

segments.question: Care of. Not to take care of these, yeah. Did you still have a desire to live in spite of that? When you went to this new camp, when you -- when you would say to me in -- in -- in Lodz, though we didn’t know the words, we were going to overcome, we were going to survive. Did you feel that, or were you --
segments.answer: Oh yes.

segments.question: You did?
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: You still felt that?
segments.answer: Yes. Why give in?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: To whom?

segments.question: Right. To yourself.
segments.answer: The Germans, to give in and let them kill me? Take my life, too? That was a different message --

segments.question: Yeah, yeah.
segments.answer: -- than -- 2

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I live and they died, and I shouldn’t live. And that’s a different --

segments.question: Different message.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: And it’s not incongruous, it’s --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- experience at the same time.

segments.question: Yeah. So you’re in this subcamp of Auschwitz in Silesia --
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: -- with part of the people who were the staff of the hospital, is that true?
segments.answer: Oh, I don’t know, then we got mixed up, totally, so it -- it was a different story.

segments.question: Uh-huh, I see. Did you know any of these people?
segments.answer: I knew a few people.

segments.question: You knew a few.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So --
segments.answer: From way back, you know, those Lodz people --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So I knew some --

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: -- the people. 3

segments.question: How bad was it in the subcamp? Was it really -- was it worse than Auschwitz, or did you now know they’re not going to gas me?
segments.answer: I didn’t know anything. They can take their way any place, anytime, so that was not unfinished story.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: But how was it? It was very cold, standing in the cold with hardly any clothes, digging ditches with very little to eat, and then coming to this tent. There was sentry, there was a little stove, a little -- you know oven, that gave a little hit -- and heat, and we could dry maybe some clothing, socks -- we didn’t have socks -- you know, on the oven, and then go to sleep. The air was good, though cold. And we huddled together, and we slept and we went up and we were up day in, day out. And in short time there was something very much that lifted our mood. And that was more often we heard airplanes buzzing overhead, and we saw at the same time the German commander and his helper looking up and crying.

segments.question: Crying?
segments.answer: Mm-hm. Those men -- those were not German airplanes, right?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You guess who it was.

segments.question: Russians.
segments.answer: Sure. And we were laughing. I-I mean, we didn’t laugh in their face, right?

segments.question: Right. So 1-in your view, something was going to happen quickly.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Did it?
segments.answer: Yes. 4

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: But before that, let me tell you one thing, in the barracks in Auschwitz. We had a -- we heard a number of times airplanes above our head, and we could go out and see the airplanes flying very low. Those were not Russians, those were American planes. With insigna -- insignias, U.S., etcetera, etcetera. And we are in the barrack, and praying in unison, drop a bomb on us. Why don’t you drop a bomb?

segments.question: On you.
segments.answer: On the barrack.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: At least --

segments.question: But then you’d be killed.
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: It didn’t matter.
segments.answer: Didn’t matter. Do something. Somebody do something. Drop a bomb on the railway. But at that point we were praying drop a bomb, just don’t be so sadistic and watch us and do nothing. Those were American planes.

segments.question: Were you -- you left in October to go to this -- this subcamp 1n Silesia, I think. Am I right?
segments.answer: Something like that, yes.

segments.question: Do you remember whether the uprising in Auschwitz had taken place, or you went to this camp before?
segments.answer: I -- we heard about it, but frankly I don’t remember much about it, and I -- I must have known more, but I don’t remember what I knew.

segments.question: You may not have been there. 5
segments.answer: I -- I might have been in the hospital.

segments.question: Right. Okay. So were you angry at the Americans?
segments.answer: And how.

segments.question: Yeah. You still are.
segments.answer: I’m still.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Of course I still am. More so later, because you know there is history now. There were people, particularly one Polish aristocrat, I forget his name, that went to Warsaw ghetto and saw what’s going on, and he went to Washington to talk to Roosevelt and to London and tell them what’s going on in Warsaw ghetto, and they wou -- didn’t want to believe him.

segments.question: Karsk1.
segments.answer: Karski, right.

segments.question: The courier.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Mm. That was [indecipherable]
segments.answer: That what confirmed the airplanes going above our heads and doing nothing.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: What cynicism. And Roosevelt saying we -- first we have to finish the war, then we’ll think about the Jews.

segments.question: Nothing much has changed, has it?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Mm. Do you escape from this camp in Silesia?
segments.answer: Escaped from the route. I told you how the rou -- how the Germans reacted to the -- 6

segments.question: Mm.
segments.answer: -- sight of planes, and probably to the news that they were getting through the radio and so on. You know, they knew more than just the planes, they knew the army -- the Russians are coming.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So one day we get the order to get ready to march. We going to the west. And then when the Death March, so-called Death March started -- you know about that, right?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Evacuating the camps to the west. So we got ready to the March. What -- how should we get ready, w-we had nothing.

segments.question: Nothing to pack, huh?
segments.answer: Nothing to pack and nothing to worry about, who to li -- leave behi-behind or not. And the -- they had a good number of German women, SS women, and they packed their things, and they went into the wagon, a big wagon, the women. And they -- we, the -- the slaves, had to pull that wagon with the -- those German madams sitting there, taking turns, and that was a added bonus for the Death March. So we were going and going and going, and where are we going? We didn’t know where we going. You know what happened, the Death March ended in Bergen- Belsen, right, on the west border. We didn’t dare s -- to slow down, because if you slowed down, you were dead. You know, the -- you know, they shoot the women, many women were shot on the way.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So you have to use all your strength to go. And on the third day I said I -- wherever we going I won’t make it because I am totally exhausted. And that night we were finished at a farm, at a big farm, and slept over, on the ground of course, under cover. And th -- in that farm there were 7 in -- under a shed, there were three big kettles of molasses. They were making molasses, okay? Hungry as we were, you know what we did. We threw us -- ourselves on the molasses and ate the molasses and you know what happened later. Diarrhea and vomiting.

segments.question: Oh my gosh.
segments.answer: And I wake up, and I said, which way do I want to die. I have to find a way, because I am not making it. So at that time I was talking with a friend of mine, you know, a neighbor on my street from before the war, and in the same class, graduating from Rumkowski’s high school. And she too said, well, we have to think about something. So we started to think and work together. And what we were observing is that we are going through one village after another with a very narrow village street -- road, really, and that the houses beyond the fence looked empty, and we don’t see any people there. You know, one village after another. So the conclusion was that they eva -- they evacuated the Germans earlier, wherever. So we thought, well, 1t will be easy enough to get to one of the houses if we think about it. And that’s one way, taking a chance. If Germans are there, we are dead. If we march we are dead, so what do you have to lose? So we picked a time where the sentries were not in the -- at the place that we were close by, but you know, it was a very long line of women marching. Started with a thousand women and shrinking. So the sentries were sort of spaced, so we thought, well, that’s time. And we just didn’t have to go far to the right, we were marching that way, houses were here. And we opened the door -- you know, the -- undone the door, and we go in. And then, on the left hand side was a barn, so we go around the barn and get into the barn and jump into the stack of hay, and stay quietly there.

segments.question: Inside the hay.
segments.answer: Inside the hay. And we heard the march going on, and in not too long time, it was quiet, so they passed. So we waited longer, longer, til it cleared, til it was to -- completely quiet and got 8 dark. And started to listen what’s going on on this side. And we heard voices. We heard voices, and we heard a language -- a Slavic language but could not distinguish. It was not Polish, but we knew that 1-in Germany there were many workers -- farm workers taken from Russia, from Ukrainia, from Belarus. So that all could be there. So after we got some reasonably time, we said, oh we have to go and see who is there. So we went and opened the door, and say hello, and happy to see you, and there were few women and few men sitting around. And they don’t look very favorably at us. And they say -- they -- they didn’t say anything, they knew who we are. Shaved heads, you know, schmates on us. So we say, yes we just run away from the -- from the march, and we ask for help, kindly. You are Jews. Get out of here. Okay. There was no way to discuss an answer like that coming from the group. So we left, and we were in the -- you know, on the outside again, and what to do? Well -- and they also said there are Germans in the village, and they will catch you. So we thought they may be right, they don’t have to be right. Our thinking was clear, you know, in all that, the thinking was clear. So we look around, and started to explore slowly. And what we see on the street in the middle of the road, many dead German soldiers, okay, with guts spilling out, and -- there was a fight, there was a battle, and left the Germans behind, so they are -- the Russians are probably advanced beyond that village. That would be then to the east, and the Russians would be going west. So finally we see a house on a little hill, so we go out there. We’re looking now for shelter. And we see the door is locked, but the key 1s hanging on the left hi -- side of the door. The family left the key so when they come back they open the door again, okay? Evacuees. So we opened the door and farn -- found a well supplied household, and food and wood and coal, you know, to heat and to eat and get sick from overeating. And we made ourself at home there. And y -- cured our stomach eventually by, you know, getting to some normal eating. And then what do we do? It’s quiet, nobody moves. The 9 next few days we were explore the village slowly, seeing if somebody is there or not, and we didn’t find anybody so we were just, you know, nursing ourselves. It was warm and clean, and clean linen, and clean clothing, it was paradise. A German paradise. We can laugh now, huh?

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: So we say w-w-what’s happening? And one night we hear marchers, you know, thump, thump on the road. We could oversee the road, the main road, east west, and we say who -- it’s a army we hear, who can it be? Either Germans or Russians. We didn’t dare to move, but eventually we say we have to see who it is. So we were slowly walking down that hill and looking and trying to find who they are, and what we saw was a lot of white. A lot of white horses, white, little horses. Soldiers on the horses are marching in white, and white hats and white fur. I say, well it looks like Siberia, you know, snow. So that -- perhaps they are Russian. So we go closer, eventually, and then we had no doubt they are Russians, you know? Because -- indeed, you know, the white hats and white thing and white horses. Everything to camouflage in Siberia, but that was winter, so that served everywhere in that part of Europe. And we see, you know, officers on horses along the marchers and we say, well, let’s take a chance, let’s go and talk to the officers. So we approach couple officers and we threw ourself in their arms and say, thank God, you are saving us, you know that? Well, they were glad to hear that, you know. They- you know. So -- and we felt perfectly safe. So we asked, where you going? Na Berlin.

segments.question: Ah.
segments.answer: Okay. So I say, so what will be with us, aren’t you going to stay here? And -- we were naive. And then they say no, we have to go -- we go to get Berlin, to free Berlin, and in couple days in a different un -- different units will come here to stay, to -- the occupation army. So wait, they will come. Well, we were jubilant, you understand, right? Our saviors are just here. Two, three days 0 pass, and then we see a bunch of young women marching 1n the direction of our house, because our house was lit. And as they come closer, we see those are our friends, those are the girls from Auschwitz. We know them. But they look -- they didn’t look the same. So they come closer, and we say, what happened to you? And they say, well, we were raped by the Russian army. And they are coming here, too. They were much more east, so you know, the Russians encountered them. Wow. They didn’t want to stay, they wanted to go forwards, I don’t know -- they had their plans how to go. And then is what are we going to do? We --

segments.question: Never st -- never stops, right?
segments.answer: Never stops.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: We were forewarned, that’s true. So, in another few days, and the army is marching again, and few officers are coming our way, every one with a bottle of whiskey in their hands. And they oh, they hug us, my -- my was lublu. We love you. Let’s have a party. So we -- w-we knew already, but we are forewarned. We prepared a bundle to run away beforehand. And then we said, you know, come to the living room and sit down and they didn’t need e-encouragement or more invitation, so they came and sat down, and we said, my was lublu, too, but we will join you in few minutes, just be patient. And we --

segments.question: Could you speak Russian? Some Russian, no?
segments.answer: You could -- few words in Polish, you know, so y-you could make yourself understandable.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So we go and grab our bundles and go the back door to the road. And the Russians are marching, you know, those were hu-humangous armies, you know? They are marching and we ask them, where is your headquarters? So they told us, more east -- no, more west, and they were 1 going, too. As you know they going now Berlin. So we [indecipherable] -- no, actually they said, they -- the headquarters were most -- more east from they were coming. So they go west, we go east, and after awhile, we -- we chance upon the -- a small house that wa -- you know, a -- a cottage, really, German cottage, and the headquarters. And we ask to be led to the chief, to the commander, and we tell the commander the story, where we from, and that we want -- we are on our way back home to Poland, Lodz, and would he -- and the danger of his soldiers, being raped, etcetera, would he help us to get -- get back home? And he says yes, we’ll help you. And he says go to the kitchen, th-there are our women working, you join them, and -- and you can stay here. So another chapter started. We were with the girls, the Russian girls in the kitchen, peeling potatoes, doing other things, and was fun. They are -- they were very friendly, they were singing all the time. And that part was fine. And we pel -- felt pretty safe. We slept -- so during the day we were in the kitchen. At night -- it was the front line. From there, soldiers were going to the front for the day, at night they came back to sleep. They were eating dinner in the dining room, and then they were sleeping on the floor, and we were sleek -- sleeping on the tables in the dining room. And it was pretty safe. It was -- it was good.

segments.question: It’s safer than being in the hay.
segments.answer: Much.

data: Much safer. We have to change the tape. End of Tape Nine 2 Beginning Tape 10

segments.question: Paula, would you have considered that liberation? When you were with these -- the Russians, and you’re sleeping on the tables, and the Russian soldiers are sleeping on the floor, I mean, were you then free?
segments.answer: We are on the way home.

segments.question: On the way home. So you’re going east.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: You’re going towards Lodz.
segments.answer: Towards Lodz. W -- our road to -- was to go west.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: No, east.

segments.question: East.
segments.answer: East, yes, mm-hm.

segments.question: But are you -- do you consider yourself liberated from the Germans cause there are no Germans any more?
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Yes.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So is there a -- a moment of -- you know, liberation is a very funny word, and I never un -- I never know when -- is there really a moment when you feel free? It doesn’t s -- 1t seems a little impossible. It seems as if it’s a -- a process as opposed to a moment.
segments.answer: I think it’s a process, and we were on the way.

segments.question: Uh-huh. 3
segments.answer: And don’t forget, we were on the front.

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: Right? The Russians were fighting to go -- they were going west, and they were fighting their way -- na Berlin, the goal was Berlin.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: They were -- they were far from Berlin still.

segments.question: Uh-huh. Right, right.
segments.answer: So -- and there was no way of knowing if the Germans won’t get back. You know, they could conquer -- a-and that what happened in that war. They were -- you know, they were not giving up easily.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Was the western armies or -- or the Russian armies. So we -- we knew that there is a big strength that -- of -- of the --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- Germans. But they were, you know, the Russians were fight it -- fighting. And listening to their mood -- na Berlin and, the army’s going na Berlin, ah, we are fighting with them.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: You know? It’s happening. It’s a turnaround. So we were just jubilous together with the -- with them.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: On the other hand, we knew that every morning troops were going out to the front that was not far away. We -- we heard fightings, you know the shelling of each other, all day, and then the soldiers came dead me -- you know, tired, home to the base, which was a small house, and they 4 were, you know, eating dinner, and -- and then conking out on the floor, going to sleep. So it was in the center of the war.

segments.question: Right. What -- how was your being Jewish treated? Did they care? Were they sympathetic, were they -- they di -- or what --
segments.answer: No, we were so happy, so when we were sitting with the soldiers and eating dinner, they ask us about -- and a -- as I tol -- told you, between Polish and Russian we could understand each other, with difficulties, but we could make ourself understood, and they ask about us, where we come from, who we are. So we were telling we are Jewish, we come from Auschwitz, and we are ready to go home, thank you. And then one day, after a few days of such liberal talks, two officers approached us, me and Vonda, and they introduced themselves, and they say, we are Jewish. And we -- we -- we hear what you saying to the Russian soldiers and please stop telling them that you are Jewish. They don’t know we are Jewish. They hate Jews. So don’t tell them who you are. We will help you. Wow, that was a slap in the face. You know, to the liberators we cannot say we are Jewish. But those were astute officers, and they were Jews, and they -- we sensed that they know very well what they are talking about. And we were not surprised then.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: So what’s new?

segments.question: Right. It’s the same story.
segments.answer: You know? Hm?

segments.question: Same story.
segments.answer: Same story. So that was that.

segments.question: So no more talk about who you are?
segments.answer: No. 5

segments.question: And how did they help you, these officers?
segments.answer: Oh, they were just keeping an eye on us for safety and so on. So just was good to know that we have some comrades here that know what’s cooking, and --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- share with us, so that was a good feeling. Friendship.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: This kind of a --

segments.question: So did you stay with that group for awhile?
segments.answer: We stay there for awhile, and they are promising us that they -- they are working on set -- on putting a train together that will go from that point to south Poland. And when the train is ready, we are free to go. And it did not take very long. They told us, and they drove us to the station when the train was set. And we took a train and arrived in Lodz one day.

segments.question: And you went back to Lodz because you thought what? You thought your father would come? Did you think anyone would be there?
segments.answer: We didn’t think.

segments.question: You didn't think.
segments.answer: We were just wanting to go home.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Knowing that there’s nobody, you know. I didn’t have illusion that Mother will be there, or Father, or my sister.

segments.question: Right, right.
segments.answer: But that’s home.

segments.question: Right. 6
segments.answer: That’s all I knew about home. My city.

segments.question: And when you got there, a lot of survivors had come back, yes?
segments.answer: Not a lot, but some.

segments.question: But survivors from other circumstances came, not just from Lodz. Am I correct, or not?
segments.answer: Well, first of all, there were the remnants of Jews in Lodz that stayed, you know, because of they were needed to clean up --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- the -- the -- the quarter, and they were coming out of their holes now, you know, openly. So they were there, and they were pre -- in pretty good shape, I have to tell you know, you know? They probably -- they could not stop thanking God for what happened, that they were allowed -- you know --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- that their things were so different from others. There were people that coming from the camps, very few. And for a long time, weeks, we sort of saw that that’s it, nobody else survived.

segments.question: Ah, out of the whole --
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: -- Europe.
segments.answer: That -- that that is -- that is all. So we tried to -- to live. We got assigned a apartment, and that was an apartment that Germans were living in and then they evacuated, they -- they went west, to Germany. So we had an apartment. We had no job, there were no jobs to be had, we had no money. The Jewish Committee that was trying to form itself was very weak and inefficient. And there was not much help that they could give us, me, my friend and some others. So life was very, very hard. And what do we do? We wanted to enroll at school, at the university. Lodz did 7 not have a university before the war. It was opening, and they had a medical faculty. So that was not possible to get to that, so I enrolled in natural sciences, and tried to go to school, which was very hard to do, you know, we were not there, mentally. So life was hard and there was a question how do we survive.

segments.question: And you were together with your friend.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Wanda -- Vonda?
segments.answer: Vonda.

segments.question: Wanda?
segments.answer: Yes. How do we survive? Then there were the opportunities to make sa -- a living, where for men, following, you know, after a war, and the war was not finish really, but Russians were in Lodz so it was a city occupied. Usually it 1s -- people live from black market, you know, exchanging -- exchanging dollars, zlotys and so on. And a big thing was ba -- bringing food stuff to the west, to the German border, and exchanging it for other things like linen and so on, and then coming to Poland and se-selling linen for money and living on that. The only thing that there was a different between a -- men and women, men were very comfortable doing it. As a woman you had to be prepared to get raped on the way. That was the -- the law of post-war without org -- or-order, without police, without anything. You know, you --

segments.question: Rape w -- rape was common’?
segments.answer: Absolutely. You had to count on that. And some women didn’t mind, or got used to that, and we didn't want to do that, so we were like that. Then comes along a friend of Vonda’s, whom she knew from ghetto. And she introduced me to him, and that was my future husband. And pe -- ex- husband. And it was a typical story of a woman that cannot support herself, poor thing, so she 8 has to have a man who does. Is not rich, but he came also, you know, from Auschwitz, but he went to his little town close to Lodz, and his parents had a little factory of producing oil from grain. And he started this factory and he was making money. Not much, but enough to be very, effusively generous with us, helping us with bread and butter. And from little to little, you know, I was caught in that gratefulness. Had sex, and once I had sex, my Mama told me, that’s your husband.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: You marry him.

segments.question: Period.
segments.answer: My mother was dead, but that I imagined what Mother would say.

segments.question: She never said that to you, but you imagined --
segments.answer: You had to be a virgin --

segments.question: Uh-huh, right.
segments.answer: -- when you married.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And the Jewish law was when you marry -- when you have sex, you -- you are married, if you didn’t know it.

segments.question: It’s not a great -- no, I didn’t know this.
segments.answer: I’m telling you.

segments.question: It’s a good thing.
segments.answer: I wish I would be so smart. So yeah, that was a terrible thing, because from the day one, I didn’t think he’s a -- you know, he 1s a partner for me. But I was grateful, that’s true and that’s fine. But wi -- I was [indecipherable] myself, feeling obliged by Jewish law to be his partner. 9

segments.question: Were you attracted to him?
segments.answer: Not really.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But it was a question of loneliness, of no food, of having sex. And I was not a femist -- feminist then, free of my mother’s beliefs about sex and marriage go together like a dove and carriage, yes?

segments.question: Yeah, yeah. Yeah. You need to go farther, I guess.
segments.answer: That’s right, and leave that, and go on. That what I should have --

segments.question: What was he like? When you say you -- you knew instinct -- that he really wasn’t going to be a partner, so was he not an intellectual, was he not a sensitive --
segments.answer: Totally unintellectually.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Totally insensitive. Totally -- good heart he had, you know, in part, you know, to help Vonda and me, and that was of his good heart. He hel -- opened his house in that little town to some relatives, they were coming also, from everywhere. And feeding them, and giving them sleep, etcetera, so he was good in that way, and warm. But nothing else. Not a man to -- man to talk with, to discuss things, and y-you know, that’s -- that was a big miss, and I was just poor little girl needing somebody to take care of her. I was not raised for that, but that’s how it felt.

segments.question: Did -- did Vonda say to you, what are you doing?
segments.answer: Vonda was married in ghetto to a guy, and he came back from war --

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: -- at that same time, so she was --

segments.question: She was set. 0
segments.answer: She was set.

segments.question: She --
segments.answer: She told me not to marry him, but I was not ready to listen. I knew myself that [indecipherable] don’t, but I did anyhow.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: [indecipherable] of being alone, lonely, unhappy, abandoned by the world, by everybody. Poor thing. And he gives me shelter.

segments.question: Sure, makes sense.
segments.answer: Right.

segments.question: Probably happened a --
segments.answer: But I didn’t have to pay the price for it.

segments.question: Well, no, I guess --
segments.answer: I didn’t. But I did.

segments.question: But you did, yeah.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: But you didn’t know. Or you didn’t know how not to do it.
segments.answer: I didn’t know how not to do that.

segments.question: And I’m sure this is true, this is a very common kind of story, right?
segments.answer: Aprow -- yes. It is the sort of morality that enslaved women, that their sexuality is not theirs, but a man’s, and they have no say over it.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: It’s very hard to get away from it.

segments.question: Absolutely. 1
segments.answer: We’re still not, as women, out of the woods, to comfortly -- comfortably to distinguish a relationship, sexuality, laws, etcetera. Men have no problem. Men were doing it all the time.

segments.question: Including during your time.
segments.answer: Including during war time.

segments.question: It’s not a new thing.
segments.answer: Not a new thing.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And we have a long way to go.

segments.question: Yeah. How long did you stay in Poland together? You -- so you -- when did you get married, ’46, °47?
°46.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: So, very soon after you came back.
segments.answer: That’s right.

segments.question: Are you going to school when you got married? Cause you started school before?
segments.answer: No, I enrolled in school before I was married, but then -- what happened then too, as I told you, I intended to stend -- stay in Poland because I thought that’s my country, and you have no right to kick me out, German or Pole -- or the Polacks. But what started then, if you don’t know, pogroms started in Poland, around in small towns, in Lodz Jews were killed. There were famous killing in southern Poland, Kielce, where Jews were killed for nothing. And it was frightful. You know, it was just a second ch-chapter of killing Jews, but now from Polacks, which was not a big surprise. But after that war? So there was a big exodus from Poland by Jews to Germany. Why 2 Germany? Because Germany was divided and occupied, you know, by the western powers and by Russia. And that was Germany, particularly American occupation that we were aiming for. Was a window out of Europe, and that was my resolve. I have enough of that continent, I’m getting out. So that was -- we went to Germany, smuggled, of course, you know, through the border. It was a big exodus, many people left. But in Germany, what happened? The big powers organized DP camps, displaced people camps, in which they put Jews, and Jews were in those camps for five, six years, cause nobody wanted to give them a visa, okay? So that was another eye opener, you know, where you going? So I enrolled in school, the university opened in Frankfurt [indecipherable] in medical faculty, and I enrolled, and I could do it because German government paid for tuition, it was the beginning of reparations for -- you know, for Jews after the war. It took me five years, I started in Lodz, five years to get my diploma, and the visa cames at that time too. So I was ready to go with my M.D. title, to America.

segments.question: And your husb -- your husband, was he shocked that you were going to medical school? I mean, this was not ordinarily in the 40’s to -- for a woman -- maybe it was in Europe, I don’t know. Certainly wasn’t here.
segments.answer: In Europe this was much more acceptable.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: And in that way I should say I admired him. He let me do what I wanted. He let me work, make money and he took the money and gambled it away. He was a gambler.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Mm-hm. So I was grateful. I could work.

segments.question: You were gra -- but you couldn’t have your own money.
segments.answer: Of course not. 3

segments.question: So, you graduated with a medical degree in what? What sort of medical doctor were you at that time, after five years?
segments.answer: Medical, general medical.

segments.question: Just general med-medical degree.
segments.answer: That’s right.

segments.question: So then, you came to this country in *51?
segments.answer: Right. And hi -- I had a son two years old.

segments.question: So while you were finishing medical school, you had a son?
segments.answer: Right, David.

segments.question: Wow, that’s a lot.
segments.answer: Yes, I always did a lot.

segments.question: You always did a lot.
segments.answer: Don’t you get the feeling?

segments.question: I get the feeling, yes.
segments.answer: Oh, my. I was capable, and I liked doing a lot. You know, I -- I had the energy to do --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- and enjoying it, yes.

segments.question: Yes. And did your husband help? Was he good with David?
segments.answer: Yes. [indecipherable]. But I -- I was so grateful to him that he -- you know, most husband didn’t like their wives to work or make money, right?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Stay home, you know, that was the common cry.

segments.question: Right. 4
segments.answer: And he was different, he let me -- he helped me studying, he took care of David. You know, 1- it was So nice.

segments.question: Well, you were also a way for him to have money so he could gamble, given what you said.
segments.answer: Of course, of course.

segments.question: Yes, hm.
segments.answer: He trained me so he can [indecipherable]

segments.question: Where did you go in the United States when you came here?
segments.answer: Cincinnati.

segments.question: Why Cincinnati?
segments.answer: Tell you why. The idea was, when the visa finally came, through the Jewish institution HIAS, and you know, then there was a question where do I go. So they assigned you where to go. So my first assignment was Seattle, Washington. You -- you won’t think I am so smart any more after I tell you that story. What do I know about Seattle, Washington?

segments.question: I have no idea.
segments.answer: I had nobody to talk to that knew anything. So I took out the map.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: And I look, America, Seattle, ocean, Russia. I want you to know, when we left Europe, since the end of the war til we left, we lived in a constant fear that the Russia is going to overrun Europe, that they are not finished. So there was always a fear that Russia will overrun. I was infected by that, too, stupidly. So there is Russia, and here is Seattle, a inch on the map.

segments.question: So you really got afraid?
segments.answer: Yes. Three -- we --

segments.question: It’s too close. 5
segments.answer: Next door.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: I said, I don’t want to go there. Would you change, kindly. They changed. Next assignment came, El Paso, Texas. I consult the map again. And I look at the map and I see El Paso. It’s the end of the States. Mexico. Cowboy coun -- Texas. It’s cowboy country. And beforehand I told the guys at HIAS, one thing I won’t go to is New York or Chicago.

segments.question: Really?
segments.answer: Right. Cause that’s Al Capone country.

segments.question: Both is Al Capone country?
segments.answer: New York had something else, but you know, those are -- you know, and I don’t want to be there. I just want you to tell -- to know. Before the war, the idea of going to America was a horrible idea for most Jews. Only deserted of Russian army --

segments.question: Went to --
segments.answer: -- would go, or adventurers, or gamblers were going to America.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: A nice girl like I would not go to America. So New York, and Chicago were the biggest centers of that. Well, anyway, El Paso I told them, that’s cowboy country, and I-I don’t know about that. At that time friends of mine were already in Cincinnati, you know, with the same past history. So we corresponded, and we -- I told them the story, and they said, why don’t you come to Cincinnati? I said, how can I come to Cincinnati, I am dependent on HIAS and all that. And they se -- nevermind, they will ship you to -- to New Orleans from -- from Hamburg, and when you are in New Orleans, we will call the leaders there, and they will ship you to Cincinnati. And 6 that’s what happened. We were entering New Orleans, and then we correspond -- I mean, there were telephones and so on, and they put us on a train from New Orleans to Cincinnati.

segments.question: And did you have a job in a hospital, though?
segments.answer: Oh, well, no. We were just --

segments.question: You were just there.
segments.answer: We were just there, in Cincinnati, no job. And he -- he got a job, finally. And you know the institutions, Jewish institution were helpful in the beginning, supportive, til he was making money. And that’s how we start our life here.

segments.question: So when did you start your practice?
segments.answer: I had to do my state board.

segments.question: Right. Did you speak English? I just thought of this.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: Of course you didn’t.
segments.answer: But I took one year English in school, as an additional foreign language.

segments.question: When? Way back?
segments.answer: In high school, way back. [indecipherable]

segments.question: And that was enough?
segments.answer: Then I learned, I worked and I learned.

segments.question: And the medical terms, of course, are the same. Or --
segments.answer: Different language.

segments.question: Different la --
segments.answer: Or the -- the Latin was the same.

segments.question: Latin’s the same. 7
segments.answer: Yes.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But different language.

segments.question: So when did you pass your boards?
segments.answer: I think ’55. We came in ’51, I did my internship and residency in -- in medicine. I could not take the board before because they had a problem with recognizing certain schools in Germany as worthy of -- you know, to acknowledge the graduation. So it took them few years, and finally I got the news that your school is recognized. So I took the state board, and then I was a doctor.

segments.question: Then you were a doctor?
segments.answer: Yes.

data: We have to change the tape. End of Tape 10 8 Beginning Tape 11

segments.question: Did you start working as a doctor right after you passed your boards 1n ’55?
segments.answer: I opened my practice in ’57.

segments.question: And this was a family pract -- this was a --
segments.answer: Family medicine.

segments.question: Family medicine.
segments.answer: Mm-hm, yeah.

segments.question: So when did you decide to be -- to do psychiatry?
segments.answer: I was about, you know, close to 15 years in practice, in family practice. And then I realized that I -- you know, I had a lot -- my practice was mainly women -- women and children, very few men. Family, so the husband would come and so on, but mainly women. And I was taken aback by observing how many women suffered from depression, deep depression. And that was a well- to-do suburb of Cincinnati, where families were ma -- mainly coming to work with Cincinnati with General Motors, Ford company, PNG. So they were -- the husband were -- had good jobs. The wives were taking care of the house and children, and I would see them in my office, and they would come with all kinds of physical symptoms. And we did the work and nothing showed. So I would have to tell them that I could not find anything else, so I don’t know why you -- why you hurt here and there. And try to sort of enlarge the questioning, what and how. I was doing a lot of house calls, not because I was so generous, but maybe I wanted -- I was used to house calls back home. But I wanted to get to know the country I am living in, and that was a very good way to do it, to see people’s homes, and how they lived. So I know the ones -- one thing I knew that was very stressful, and that was the big companies were promoting people, but you paid a price for it. The promotion would come and you had to move to another part of the 9 country. If you get the promotion in Cincinnati, you would be sent to the west coast, and from the west coast you would be sent to Cincinnati. So the family was always in a turmoil, having to live with the idea that every two years you have to move, if you want to move up the ladder. And it was the wife that had to put in roots quickly, school, church, neighborhood. I knew that that was a chore, but they were always sen -- saying that they are treated well -- they are treated well. The husband really didn’t move. He was still in the circles of national commerce, or productivity. But the wife had to change totally her surrounding, and make it easy for the husband. So I know -- knew that, but beyond that I didn’t know. And I had friends, they were either in training of psychiatry, or psychiatrists, and they told me about it, and what -- and I didn’t know anything about Freudian psychiatry in Germany. We were learning psychiatry, you know, but not about Freud. So, you know, the dynamic psychiatry, it was fresh to me, and it was exciting, so I said, I ka -- I have to do it. That’s -- I went into training.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: And that was very exciting, and that was good. Listen, I have to tell you part of my story that I omitted, and I ashamed of that. But it is very hard. And that -- I told you I had another son, right?

segments.question: Yes, yes.
segments.answer: I was -- when I came to America, I was pregnant -- you know, David was two years old and I was pregnant. And then Charlie was born in ’51, still the same year we came. And he was a lovely child, so I had two children, right, and fine. He developed -- what can I say? He developed psychological problems, was in therapy. We did not recognize the depth of his depression. Eventually he committed suicide. He was 21. So that is a thing I don’t like to talk about. You understand why. Big pain. 0

segments.question: Yeah. Is that also one of the reasons why you d -- wanted to go into psychotherapy?
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: It was quite separate.
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: Course it’s painful, it’s horrible. And David is two years older?
segments.answer: Two and a half years older, mm-hm.

segments.question: Should I ask you something? I don’t -- I --
segments.answer: Yes, go ahead.

segments.question: Did y -- did you understand und -- at any point before he died, how deep the depression was? How -- how -- how much 1n pain he was, or was that too hard to tell?
segments.answer: I knew some, but obviously I did not understand how deep it was.

segments.question: Mm, mm.
segments.answer: And how dangerous it was --

segments.question: Yeah.
segments.answer: -- to his life.

segments.question: Yeah. Did David? His so -- his brother.
segments.answer: Neither.

segments.question: Nobody.
segments.answer: No. He was in therapy.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: But I don’t think the psychiatrist understood it too. 1

segments.question: So it seems as 1f no one could have -- I mean, there were no -- there were not enough signs for someone -- and it’s not clear that one can do anything --
segments.answer: That’s right.

segments.question: -- under those circumstances. And why did you say you were ashamed? You were ashamed because you didn’t say it.
segments.answer: That’s right.

segments.question: Oh.
segments.answer: If -- to -- as if to deny his existence, you know?

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Which I don’t want to do --

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: -- but it is too hard to talk about it, so --

segments.question: And I must admit, I was hesitating to ask you. I knew. I didn’t know this -- I didn’t know any part of the story, but I was hesitating. So it’s -- it’s very tough. When were you divorced?
segments.answer: °73. Charlie died in ’73, too.

segments.question: Sure. Wow. So that was quite a year.
segments.answer: You can say that.

segments.question: I don’t know, your life has these arcs of so many difficulties, and so -- and at the same time, accomplishments. No?
segments.answer: I don’t know, I don’t treat it as accomplishment. It was work that I had to do.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: Work I had to do to survive the war in the ghetto, in Auschwitz. You know, to bear witness, which I am doing now. 2

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Just to tell the story that it -- it really was.

segments.question: And when did you start talking about the Holocaust? Did you talk with your sons? I know you couldn’t talk with your husband, he -- he would not speak about any of his experiences.
segments.answer: With my sons I talked, but very little.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: Facts, giving facts.

segments.question: But they didn’t know your experience.
segments.answer: No.

segments.question: No.
segments.answer: Certainly not in details how we talk now. So the silence was horrible.

segments.question: Did you want to speak?
segments.answer: I could not speak.

segments.question: You couldn’t.
segments.answer: I could not speak. I could tell them some, but then I -- I -- I couldn’t go any farther. And people didn’t want to listen --

segments.question: I was going to ask, yeah.
segments.answer: -- including my children.

segments.question: Uh-huh.
segments.answer: So that was a sort of silence over the whole experience.

segments.question: Right.
segments.answer: Individually, and as a Jewish experience.

segments.question: So, the people that you met in Cincinnati didn’t say what happened? 3
segments.answer: There was a group of people, of Jews, that came here at the same time, about the same time, with similar experiences. And I was involved with that group. One was the friend that, you know, asked me to come, you know, from se -- from New Orleans here. Where it was by and large not a comfortable group, the same way as my relationship with my husband was not because he was not on my level, and we had very little in common in communicating and talking about things, and -- but that group was the same cut of people. We were celebrating holidays together, we had parties like, you know, for holidays. The advantage of being part of the group was one. We knew about our experiences, and we didn’t have to talk about it, where we from. We all had the same experience, and 1-it was just being together, and not to have -- to explain yourself, or listen to explanation.

segments.question: Mm-hm.
segments.answer: But then, at the same time that I was contemplating moving away from my husband, my relationship with that group also broke off. And it was funny and not funny how it did. You see, that group was strictly Polish Jews of tradition and Jewishness, and patriarchy, and the woman is a woman and I am the man. You know, in Jewish law, a woman cannot divorce a husband. The husband always can divorce the woman, to the degree that if there is not a rabbi, he can tell the woman, I divorce you, I divorce you, I divorce you, and that e-equals divorce, when you tell it to the rabbi. But a woman cannot divorce a man. I didn’t un-understand that for a long time, but then, after I divorced my husband, that wo -- group turned against me, they stopped talking to me. And I didn’t understand why til I became c -- became clear to me that I did do the unspeakable, I divorced a man. A woman divorced a man. So I was not sorry about breaking off the relationship, but what made me very angry was realized why it happened. 4

segments.question: Mm-hm. So ts the -- the -- the next -- the next person with whom you actually talk about your experiences Lanzmann? Because that’s in the next couple of years, right? Or is it --
segments.answer: Mm-hm.

segments.question: And once you do that, once you give that interview, do you decide, okay, now I don’t have to talk about it again? Or not?
segments.answer: I don’t know, but in the time since my divorce and all that, I was more free to talk with my friends, many of whom were Gentiles, women we got sort of all together with a group of women that we were sort of compatible, and they are all Ge-Gentiles. And I was free to talk with them about it, or even with other -- other Jews. But how it happened really, maybe the impetus was the interview with Lanzmann.

segments.question: Mm-hm. Have you spoken to students, or is this all very private? Or synagogue groups, or church groups, or --
segments.answer: No, no --

segments.question: No, no public --
segments.answer: -- I never wanted to do it.

segments.question: -- no. You didn’t want to do it.
segments.answer: No, no. I did once in a school, you know, in a public school to a group, to a class, talked about it, and that was very unsatisfactory. I didn't enjoy it, it was just not my --

segments.question: It wasn’t your cup of tea.
segments.answer: Ye -- right. So I didn’t.

segments.question: Do -- have people in the last 10 years, or m-maybe since the Lanzmann film, do they, when they meet you say -- ask you more questions? They don’t?
segments.answer: No. 5

segments.question: I guess I’m surprised at that. In the last 10 years? Not --
segments.answer: Be-Because they saw the -- the film?
